I think I have figured out how to do this in a way
that allows the server to move attachments to URLs
on other servers on an ad-hoc basis and that does
not require servers to maintain current view-state
for every client.  Please tell me if this solution
is too HTTP abusive.

Initially, the client makes a simple GET request
to the URL of the mailfolder.  The server returns:

  200 OK
  Content-Type: multipart/digest; boundary="abc"
  Etag: my-etag

Now, if the client want to receive only what has
changed since my-etag, it sends:

  GET /folder/url HTTP/1.1
  If-None-Match: my-etag
  Accept: multipart/byteranges

The question is whether the server is now allowed
to send a multipart/byteranges response.  RFC2616
prohibits a 206 response if the client did not
explicitly make a range request, but I think the
semantics of content negotiation would certainly
allow the server to make a 200 response with
partial content if it so desired.

What I would really like to do is have the server
return a content-range header with a
multipart/digest response.  Is there a way I can
make that legal in response to a request with a
"accept-content-range" header?

Any thoughts?

-Alex-
